cab.content: mis DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OE HIS BRITANNIC MA J ..1S TY' S GOVERNMENT)H C RJ3 T "f ^Copy No.-Pi 8X.I27)C AJD IN E T EQUAL FRANCHISE COMMITTEE.Note bthemSecretary;.The attached Note by the Chairman of the National Union of Conservative and Unionists Associations was prepared at the request of the Equal Franchise Committee and is new circulated to the Cabinet for consideration in connection with the question of Equal Franchise,(Signed) M.?.Aa RAN KEY,Secretary to the Cabinet.2 Whitehall Gardens, S.W.1, 12th March, 1927. ffote by the Obairman of the National Union of Conservative ana "Unionist" Associations.With reference to 12. IP. (26) 3rd Meeting, Conclusion 1, I enclose a Memorandum from the Central Office on the effect upon the distribution of electors in the event of an extension of Women" s Franchise to the ages of 25 and 21 respectively, in both cases on the same conditions as the present Male Franchisee The facts are summarised on pages 2 and 3 of the memorandum.The only conclusion I am able to draw from thefigures ie that as redistribution can be resisted in the face of the existing anomalies, e.g., in county Durham - Barnard Castle 21,806 electors, 1 memberGateshead 57,082 electors, 1 memberYorkshire - Dewsbury 28,816 electors, 1 memberHudderefiela 60,873 electors, 1 member to give two examples only, I do not believe that the additionof the women, even at 21, will make so much difference as tomake redistribution necessary. Redistribution could not help the Party and would probably damage it, would certainly bevery unpopular, and would cause considerable expense.(Signed) J.C.C. DAVIDS OK.Chamberlain e rs, Br i dg e S t re e t, Westminister, S".\7. 1. OHPXDEHTIAL. \ ggREDI8TRI BUTION.To "be able to form any opinion of Redistribution of Seats on a basis of population is extremely difficult. The last Census was taken in June 1981, having been postponed from the usual month of April owing to the Strike * Speaking broad-ly, the figures in Parliamentary Constituencies show that about 50$ of the population are Parliamentary Electors., The total population of Great Britain and Northern Ireland is 44,025,518,, and there are 22,195,876 Electors (excluding the Universities), There are some marked discrepancies in this percentage, as examplesPresent Pop. 1921. Electors.Mile End....... 84,413 25,218 29$Finitechapel ... 93,945 26,612 28$Romford ....... 84,450. 55,772 66$Ilford........ 85,862 55,862 65$In the Representation of Ihe People Act 1918, the census of 1911 was taken with an estimate of the population in19I78 This was very unsatisfactory, as the figures of theRegister published afterwards provede Generally speaking, withthe exception of the City of London and a few other cases inaddition to the four mentioned above., the present Electorategives a very fair estimate of the population in each Constitu-ency.Reforms of the present Electorate are sent herewith 1^ APPEXDLX A, England and Wales, showing Constituencies on anaverage of 37,200 Electors for 520 Members. APPENDIX B. Scotland, showing Constituencies on an averageof 32,708 Electors for 71 Members* APPENDIX C. Northern Ireland, showing Constituencies on anaverage of 51,439 for 12 Members. The average for -all the 603 Members of Parliament (exclusive of 11 University Members) on the present Register is 36j800 Electors.HEW E3AUGEI.S5.Taking it for granted there is no alteration of the present qualification of a man, and a woman is placed on the Register on the same conditions as a mani viz., a three months residential qualification, it is estimated on the representa-tion now existing in the House of Commons remaining at 603 Members, the following would be a fair estimateElectors^ Average ElectorsEach Constituency..Women at 30 .., 24.195,000 . 40?100. Women at 25 ... 25695,000 42,600.Women at 21 27^195,000 45,100There are a certain number of present Constituencies where it is estimated there will be an addition of women on the Register over the normal average,,, these are set out in Appendix I); and also Constituencies where it is estimated the addition of women to the Register will be below the normal average, and are set out in Appendix E*On reference to Appendixes A, B and C, it will be seen that in very few Counties, even with the addition of the new voters, will much change., on the average5 be required^ The following Counties may require additional representationDurhamEssexMiddlesex11 1SurreyWax vrx. ck sh ire eYo rks hlr s, IV. H.Whilst the following may he over-representedCumhe rland 1 Dorsetshire 1 Norfolk 1Shropshire Wiltshire1 1 11 1There are some Constituencies without addition to the total representation of the County which may require slight alteration of boundaries within the County to bring them nearer the normal averageoExcess.
